titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. IV:30. Friday. I rode with Mrs Adams to look at a house and land that are for sale near the river, and at a Square belonging to Dr Thornton, also near the river. At the Office I had visitors, Mr Fontaine Maury, brother of the Consul at Liverpool, who came to solicit an office as Clerk in one of the Departments, Mr. Alexander M’Rae who has been appointed Consul at Amsterdam; but who is not certain whether he can accept the Office, but will soon inform me. Mr Dana, who brought me a draft of a Bill which he thinks of proposing concerning the extent of our jurisdiction from the shores, and Mr Calhoun the Secretary of War, to whom I gave the despatches lately received from South America, and from Mr. Rush at London. In the Evening I had a visit from Mr Correa the Portuguese
Minister, with whom I had a long, and not very pleasant conversation. He said he had been much hurt by a paragraph in yesterday’s National Intelligencer, noticing in harsh terms the reception and ill-treatment experienced by the Congress Frigate, and the neglect of our Commissioners at Rio Janeyro— He brought me an anonymous Letter to himself written at Savannah, last November, containing an account of a Portuguese vessel taken and carried to Amelia Island, by the adventurers there, and condemned as a Spaniard— And this event he pretended had exasperated the people at Rio Janeiro, against us; and occasioned the ill treatment of our Officers. As to those Up Stairs, he said (meaning the king) there was an affair, ever since last June, which had indisposed them—meaning the Countenance given here, to Da Cruz, a man who came as deputy from the Insurgents at Pernambuco. And Count Villa Nova, the present acting Minister of Foreign Affairs, Bezerra having died last November, was a man of morose, unconciliatory temper, and strongly prejudiced against the United States. I told him, first, that the Article in the National Intelligencer, was not inserted from the Government; and I knew nothing of it— I supposed it founded upon private Letters— Secondly that the reception of the Frigate, and of the Commissioners had not been friendly. Disagreeable incidents had occurred, which however had been I hoped ultimately explained to mutual satisfaction— Thirdly that the Minister Villa Nova had made the unwarranted and inadmissible demand that all the Portuguese Sailors on board the Congress should be discharged. In that Correa said, as we never practiced impressment, the Minister Villa Nova was certainly wrong. This led us into a long discussion, about Spain, Portugal, South America, the European Alliance and this Country, in which with a pretence of Confidential Communication, and mysterious inuendos he hinted that the European Alliance had determined to take part against the South-Americans, and that Russia was to have some great foot-hold on the American Continent— It was obvious that he had some conjectural as well as some real information from Paris; and that he wished me to consider the South-American business as entirely settled by the European Alliance—I told him if they thought of settling affairs of such importance, and in which we have so deep an interest, without consulting us, they must not complain if we pursued our course concerning it without consulting them— He fully admitted our right, but in the course of our discussion there was something like acerbity, in the collision of our opinions— We parted however in mutual good humour.

2. V:30. The last Night and this Morning the weather was so warm that this day for the first time, I had no fire made in my Cabinet. But there was a Morning thunder shower followed by a day of steady and moderate rain. I made a new proposal to Jas Greenleaf and S. Eliot jr. for the two Squares about which I have been in Treaty with them; but they again declined accepting it. At the Office I had a visit from R. Kemper, who took his papers with him to consult a lawyer about them. I received various despatches from England, with one of which there was a packet for Mr Correa, the Portuguese Minister, which I immediately sent to him— In the Evening he wrote me a Note, saying that there was in his despatches some agreeable information concerning which he wished for a short interview with me. I appointed to-morrow Morning at ten O’Clock to see him.

3. IV:30. The storm continued with great violence the whole day, with rain almost incessant though not in heavy showers. Mr Correa came at ten, in high Spirits, and entirely released from his terrors, and his ominous conjectures about the European Alliance— He had a Letter from Palmella, after his return from Paris in Feby. Palmella tells him that Fernan Nuñez and he have both received their full Powers to arrange the affair of Montevideo, between Spain and Portugal— That he is determined to admit only the Mediation, and not the umpirage of the other European Powers— That he will agree to restore Montevideo, only on the preliminary condition that the affair between Spain and her Colonies shall be settled either by her acknowledgment of their Independence, or by her subduing them; of which he says the prospect is from day to day more remote— He expresses much satisfaction, at our occupation of Amelia-Island, and at
the motives assigned in the President’s Messages for that measure. He requests Mr Correa to send him all the documents relating to that affair, and says they will have great effect in justifying the occupation of Montevideo by the Portuguese Government; shewing that similar causes produced the same effects, and gave rise to measures founded on the same principles; without co’operation or even concert between the two Governments— He adds that he shall return to Paris, and protract the negotiation, until the Meeting of the kings which is to be next September at Aix La Chapelle, and which the king of Spain means to attend— There Palmella expects that this subject will be merged in the general questions about South-America, and that the whole will end in smoke. Correa said he was very much gratified to find such a perfect coincidence with the sentiments and opinions that I had expressed to him the Evening; before last. and the more so, as it was not an official despatch but a friendly and confidential Letter— He had also a Letter from the acting Minister of foreign Affairs Villa Nova, which shews he had been very polite and attentive to Captain Biddle, and which speaks with much esteem of Mr Sumter— He is therefore entirely convinced that the unpleasant incidents that occurred while the Congress Frigate was there were accidental; and that the Non-introduction of our Commissioners to the king, was owing only to the informality of their characters; and perhaps to avoid giving direct Offence to Spain, whose Minister Casa-Flores had perhaps made an extraordinary stir, upon the occasion— Mr Correa told me he should go for Philadelphia, the day after to-morrow, and asked me to hold this as his visit to take leave. The remainder of the day, with the exception of an hour’s walk in the midst of the gale, I was still absorbed in the arrangement of my Accounts, a labour so much like idleness that I can scarcely justify it to myself. There was a Mail, unusually large, of despatches from Sweden and England.

4. V: The President sent me word this morning that he had returned from his short tour to Virginia. When I called at his house I found there Mr Calhoun and Mr Crowninshield, Mr Crawford came in shortly afterwards— The despatches from General Jackson were just received containing the account of his progress in the War against the Seminole Indians, and his having taken the Spanish Fort of St. Mark’s in Florida, where they had taken refuge. They hung some of the Indian prisoners, as it appears without due regard to humanity. a Scotchman by the name of Arbuthnot was found among them, and Jackson appears half inclined to take his life. Crawford some time ago proposed to send Jackson an order to give no quarter to any white man found with the Indians. I objected to it then, and this day avowed that I was not prepared for such a mode of warfare. The despatches from South America were read, and I gave the President the two Letters to him from the Supreme Director Pueyrredon as I was leaving the President’s he said he would speak to me again about young Fenwick, and his appointment to one of the new Clerkships in the State Department. Fenwick himself came to the Office to enquire if he might expect the appointment; and I answered him rather sharply that I could not tell him. Mrs Adams spent part of the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s— I was engaged upon my Accounts— No Eastern Mail from beyond Baltimore this day.

5. V: Met Mr Crawford this Morning at the President’s. He wanted a revisal of the determination in the case of the Pennsylvania Militia fines; but it is too late. The decision was upon the opinion of the Attorney General Wirt, with which Crawford is much dissatisfied— I did not concur with it myself; but after it was given thought it useless to have further discussion concerning it. Mr Crawford went with me to my Office, and he examined the British Acts of Parliament upon which Mr Bagot claims the admission of British Vessels from Turks Island, and the Bahama’s on equal terms with our own. He doubted whether these Laws would warrant that inference; he promised to give me a further answer in a few days— Mr G. Graham called at the Office with Mr F. Maury, who solicits an appointment as Clerk; and offers now to accept one of those which are allowed by the new Law to the Department of State— B. O. Tyler who has published an engraving of the Declaration of Independence, with fac Similes of the signatures came and read me a copy of a Letter which he proposes to send to my father with a copy of it. He also brought me a letter from Gardner, with a copy of one from Mr Jefferson to him, on the subject. Mr Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister came, and had again a long Conversation with me, urging the settlement of our disputes with Spain: but always hinging upon the same points; upon which I told him that he might assure his Government with the most positive certainty that no such arrangement would be made. He said also something of the affairs between Spain and South America— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s— Mr Bailey was here and consulted me on a project which he says the Massachusetts Republicans
have of establishing a Newspaper in Boston, of which he should be the Editor to recover the ascendency of the Republican party in the Commonwealth, with a view to coalesce with the moderate federalists, and to throw off the most violent— I discouraged as much as I could this plan, from a doubt both of its utility, and of its success—Particularly as it may personally affect Bailey himself; whom I advised not to relinquish a comfortable situation for so great an uncertainty.

6— V:30. Met Mr Crawford at the President’s. I further consulted with the President, concerning the filling of the two vacant Clerkships in my Office—I determined upon giving them to Judge Thruston’sSon, and to Mr F. Maury— He came to the Office, and I informed him that he should have one of the vacancies. I received a Letter from J. Pope to G. Boyd, under cover to me, unsealed, and with a request that I would deliver it personally to Mr Boyd. It contains information that Mrs Pope is given over by the physicians, and was expected to survive but a few days. Boyd is yet absent. I communicated the Letter to my wife, who advised that it should not be shown to Mrs Boyd. I also received a Letter which has been several days expected, from M’EvanHale and Davidson, at Philadelphia— There was this Evening a long and heavy Thunder Shower.

7. IV:45. I went up to the Capitol this morning, and examined the Commissioners of the Public Buildings Coll: Lane’s Book. I found the dimensions of the two Lots in Square N. 231. which I have purchased, and many other particulars relating to the lots and Squares in the City— I likewise called at the Office of the Clerk of the Court, W. Brent, and left my deed to be recorded there— Met Mr Bulfinch, and saw the wooden Model of the Capitol which he has at his Office. His family has just arrived from Boston— When I called at the President’s he had rode out. Mr De Forrest was at the Office— I told him that he could not be recognized in the character of Consul General, as that would import a recognition of the Government of Buenos-Ayres. But if he should have any communications to make at the Department of State, they would be received with the same attention as if he was acknowledged: and I added that the supposed Treaty, which Mr Worthington had assumed to make was without any authority and had not been approved by the President. He said it had been thought ridiculous by all the Americans at Buenos-Ayres, and done solely with a view to give himself consequence—he would doubtless make a similar Treaty in Chili— But as a Consul from this Country had been appointed to Buenos-Ayres, the Director Pueyrredon had thought there would be no difficulty in receiving one. He was himself a native Citizen of the United-States, and now returned to remain here, having no intention ever to go back to South-America. His appointment was of very little consequence, and was given him unsolicited by him, with a view to prevent the irregularities which had been committed by privateers under the flag of Buenos-Ayres which the Director highly disapproved— But he asked me whether he should exhibit his Commission to me; and whether he should make an application for the exequatur in writing, to receive an answer in the same manner— I said that we had appointed many Consuls to reside at Colonial establishments they were seldom received with those regular titles, but were generally allowed to act as Colonial commercial Agents At Buenos Ayres Mr Halsey had been formally received— This was altogether a voluntary act on the part of the Government there, who might have declined it without offence to us— But the Director himself in announcing his, De Forrest’s appointment as Consul General had referred to Worthington’s Treaty which was entirely disavowed. As to writing, I thought that would be unnecessary. It would be more consistent with delicacy from each party to the other that it should be thus understood by verbal communication. If however he preferred writing, and would address a Note to me, I would send him an answer to the same effect with what I now told him— I asked him if his Commission interfered with that of Mr Aguirre; he said no— Mr Aguirre’s Commission was merely to procure arms, and naval Stores; and an armed vessel— He had no authority to ask the acknowledgment of his
Government, and he knew it was not the wish of the Director to press this Government upon that subject. But Aguirre had been instigated here, by other persons to all that he had lately done— He then asked if there was not a demand from the Director that Mr Halsey should be recalled. I told him that there was; and that Mr Halsey had been already sometime since, dismissed— There were doubts as to the President’s power, to recall, an individual Citizen from a foreign Country; but Halsey’s Commission being revoked, if the Director thought it essential that he should be personally removed he would of course be subject to the Police regulations of the Country— De Forrest asked whether he could see the President. I told him I had no doubt he could. I would mention his wish to-morrow Morning and had no doubt he would be received, if he called at the house— I sent for young Thruston and informed him that I had appointed him one of the Clerk’s in the Department— I am still too much engaged with my papers.

8. V: Met Mr Crawford at the President’s. I mentioned to the President Mr De Forrest’s desire to see him, to which he readily acceded. De Forrest came again to my Office, and I had further Conversation with him. He enquired among other things whether if the Government of Buenos Ayres, should send an expedition to take possession of Florida, the Government of the United States would take any measure to prevent it— I told him that the same Law, by virtue of which possession was lately taken of Amelia Island would apply on such contingency to the remainder of Florida; it had been in existence ever since the year 1811. and expressly provided that no foreign power could be permitted to take possession of that Province, or any part of it: The United States had a claim upon it, for indemnities which have long been due from Spain, and they cannot suffer that it should be taken out of their hands by a third party— He said the Government of Buenos Ayres had no concern in the late transactions at Amelia-Island, and were entirely satisfied with the steps taken there by the United-States. But the possession of a Port in the Gulph of Mexico, would be of great importance to them, as a means of annoyance to Spain; and unless they could take Florida, they could have no Port upon the Gulph to which their privateers could resort. I said the Law of Congress had been made, without any intention to injure the interests of Buenos-Ayres, but while it remained in force, the President was bound to have it executed. That the Commissioners to South America, had been instructed to give every suitable explanation upon that subject and no doubt had done so at Buenos-Ayres— Mr De Forrest concluded to leave the affair of his Office as Consul-General from the Provinces of La Plata, upon the ground of verbal communications, without writing; and went from the Office to the President’s, where he was received— The President had some conversation with him— Besides this appointment, the President has received another Letter from the Supreme Director Pueyrredon announcing his appointment of General William Winder of Baltimore, as deputy, from the Provinces of La Plata, to the Government of the United States. General Winder enclosed this Letter to the President, and seems undetermined whether to accept or decline it— The President will answer Winder’s Letter— Judge Thruston called at my house this evening, and thanked me for the appointment of his Son, to one of the Offices of Clerks, made under an Act of Congress passed at the last Session— I received a Note from Onis, about the L’Allemand expedition to Galveston.

9. V:15. I called at the Branch Bank, and then at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning the transfer of the Certificates of U.S. Stocks, upon the Books here— I gave Mr Nourse the Register my Certificates, as well those received from Philadelphia, as those now standing on the Books at Boston. I also called at the Comptroller Anderson’s Office, to speak about A. H. Everetts accounts, which he has not yet passed. Mr Ten Cate the Charge d’Affaires from the Netherlands was at my Office, to make enquiries concerning the late Law of Congress placing vessels of the Netherlands on the same footing as vessels of the United States, in regard to Tonnage duties— Our Law goes back to the time when the law for equalizing tonnage duties in the Netherlands took effect— Ten Cate wanted to persuade me that it should go back to 27. May 1815. Although the order officially communicated by himself refers only to a Law of 3. October 1816. I shewed Ten Cate that during the interval they had levied extra duties upon American vessels, at Antwerp. This young man pushes his point with considerable address— I did not attend at the President’s— Evening at home, and finding myself unable to write, I made it very short.

10. IV:30.Dr Hunt performed an operation yesterday on the lip of Mary Hellen; and she has a bandage over it which distresses her more than the operation itself. Mr Brent called here this Morning, having returned last Evening from his excursion to his farm in Maryland. He has been four days absent from the Office— I had also a long visit from Mr Greuhm, the Prussian Resident. He gave me an extract from a Letter of Mr Pfaffel the Bavarian Minister at London—enquiries about the Estate of a German deceased at Philadelphia— After a long spell of cold weather this was the first warm day. Took a walk with Mrs Adams to the point, and old house fronting the Potowmack, where I have had thoughts of purchasing a couple of Squares But she dislikes the place so much that I shall give up the idea— The Examination of my Accounts and affairs engrosses my time, beyond my power of resistance— It makes me neglect this journal, and even Public Business—

11. V: A man by the name of Ford came this morning to my house, to ask for an office, and with a tale of distress deeply affecting— A wife and four children without bread—himself almost crippled with rhumatism—and nothing to depend upon but this chance of an Office.— He had been a United Irishman, in the Insurrections of 1798, and upon their suppression came to this Country. He has been a merchant; a lieutenant in the army, and has now a small and precarious Office in the Custom-House at Baltimore— He cannot live upon it, and wants something better— The violence of his agitation was such when he described his wants almost convulsed him; and he read two extracts of Letters from his daughter, telling him they were pawning spoons for bread— I spoke of him to the President, and represented his case as forcibly as possible. I also sent him Ford’s letter, and that of Mr Roberts the Senator from Pennsylvania, recommending him— I called at the Bank to ask a question concerning the Bank Stock, which neither G. Graham nor Davidson could answer; but Smith the Cashier, whom I met in the Street, told me. At the Office a Mr Isaac Waters of Boston, came to solicit a new place of Custom House Appraiser there. There are a multitude of other applicants. Mr Bagot applied by Note, for an interview which I fixed for to-morrow at 2 O’Clock— The President told me he proposed to call tomorrow, or the next day, a Cabinet Meeting— This morning the weather was above Summer heat; Fahrenheit 77. towards Evening there was rain— No Fires.

12. V:15. Brought up the arrears of this Journal. It made a late Morning and I missed calling at the President’sMr Bagot came at two O’Clock, and delivered to me, the Warrant, from the Prince Regent, addressed to Sir John Coape Sherbrook the Governor General of Canada, or in his absence, to the Officer commanding in the Province of Nova Scotia; reciting the substance of the Report of the Commissioners under the fourth Article of the Treaty of Ghent, and directing him to deliver up Moose, Dudley and Frederick Islands, to any person authorized on the part of the United States to receive them. There was some question whether this warrant should be sent to Sir J. C. Sherbrook, or directly to Lord Dalhousie the Lieutenant-Governor of Nova-Scotia. It was concluded that unless the President should otherwise direct the Warrant should be sent to Lord Dalhousie, and Mr Bagot promised to send a certified copy of it to Sir John C. Sherbrook— He told me that he had received the despatches of two Month’s, February and March at once; but he had been disappointed in the expectation of having the Communication to make to me which had been promised by Lord Castlereagh, concerning what it was proposed to do with regard to South-America. I told him, I supposed it was because nothing had been agreed upon to be done. That it would have been agreeable to the President to have received this Communication, particularly as we were already in possession of the Answer of Russia, to the propositions made by Great-Britain— He said he had no doubt that the delay of the Communication was occasioned solely by the fact that nothing had been definitively agreed upon— He said he was likewise expressly instructed to present the thanks of his
Government to the President, for the delicacy of proceeding observed in the suppression of a paragraph of a Letter, among the documents first communicated to Congress respecting Amelia-Island, in which a British Officer had stated that M’Gregor’s expedition was really carried on, with the authority and at the expence of his Government— Mr Bagot said his despatch added that it could hardly be necessary to say that the Assertions of that British Officer had been totally without foundation— I sent also for Major John Davidson, and had some Conversation with him relating to private affairs— Returned to him a Certificate he had given me in the Winter; and settled with him a demand which he made in consequence of that transaction— I received a Letter for my wife, from Mr John Pope of Lexington Kentucky, under a Blank cover to me. I had no doubt the Letter contained intelligence of the Death of Mrs Pope, my wife’s Sister. I felt reluctant at giving my wife this Letter, when I returned home to dinner, and immediately after, Mrs Adams went out and spent the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s. Mr Boyd has returned from his late excursion and left Mrs Hellen, at Little York— Mrs Pope died on Friday, the 24th. of April.

13. IV: But notwithstanding I rose at this early hour, by omitting to begin the day with the journal of the day before, I made again an arrear. I began with my Accounts; an object which should be postponed to a time of easy leisure; which I have not yet, and thought I should still have enough of the morning left for the Journal. I gave Mrs Adams the Letter from J. Pope, which announced the Death of his wife at which although the event had been long expected, she was much affected. Before Breakfast I received a Note from the President, asking my attendance at a Cabinet Meeting at eleven O’Clock, and enclosing Letters from the Judges of the Circuit Court, sitting at Baltimore, and from the Attorney General recommending a pardon, or remission of a Capital sentence upon a man named Lewis Hare, for robbing the Mail. The President directed that a pardon should immediately be made out, for the capital part of the penalty, and sent by the express, who was waiting for the answer. I called at the Branch Bank and left an order on the Cashier of the U.S. Bank at Philadelphia to transfer here the balances due to me there— Sent for Mr Frye, and W. S. Smith, and communicated to them the Letter from Mr Pope to Mrs Adams.— Mr Frye promised also to make it known to Mr Boyd— Gales, one of the Editors of the National Intelligencer came to say something about the printing of public documents— I had some conversation with him on the expediency of importing one of Konig’s completing Machines, for the public printing, but found upon examination that it would not effectually answer the purpose of having the printing done with much greater expedition than at Present— At eleven O’Clock, I attended the Cabinet meeting at the President’s. He proposed several questions for Consideration. 1. Whether Amelia-Island should with or without a new application from the Spanish Minister, be evacuated? 2. Whether if the War with the Seminole Indians should come to an end, by their surrender, our troops shall evacuate Florida? 3. Whether an armed force shall be sent, to visit both sides of the Coast of South-America, for the protection of our Commerce, and to countenance the Patriots. To which was added the further question, whether a Frigate should also be sent into the India Seas? 4. Whether a person of confidence should be sent to Galveston, to ascertain by what authority the late Settlement there has been made; and to give warning that it is the Territory of the United States. 5. Whether the Ministers of the United States in Europe shall be instructed, that the United States will not join in any project of interposition between Spain and the South-Americans, which should not be to promote the complete Independence of those Provinces, and whether measures shall be taken to ascertain if this be the policy of the British Government, and if so to establish a concert with them for the support of this policy. 6. Whether any measures shall be taken with regard to the renewal of the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. with Great-Britain. All these points were discussed without much diversity of opinion, upon any of them. It was agreed that neither Amelia-Island nor Florida should be evacuated for the present— As to sending an Agent to Galveston nothing definitive was determined— There were incidental questions, with regard to the kind of agent
to be sent, whether ostensible, or secret; and from which of the Departments. No positive decision was made. It was concluded to send a frigate and a Sloop of War, one into the India Seas and the other on the South American Coast— The conclusion with regard to the Commercial Convention of July 1815 was that since our late Navigation Act, we might propose to Great-Britain the simple renewal of the Convention, and express at the same time our willingness to negotiate with them further for other objects, if they should be so inclined— The point upon which there appeared the most variety of opinion was on the Instructions to be given to our Ministers abroad, concerning the Spanish and South-American quarrel— I thought that instead of one general circular instruction, there should be different Instructions given, and a different course prescribed to different Ministers; and particularly that no proposal should be made to Great-Britain, for concerted measures with her to promote the Independence of South-America— First, because it would be a departure from neutrality— Secondly, because Great-Britain though she will readily acquiesce in the South-American Independence, will cautiously avoid having the appearance of supporting it; and thirdly, because she would at once decline our overture, and make it an engine to injure us, with the other European Powers. Finally, the President directed me to make drafts of Instructions to Mr Gallatin, Mr Rush and Mr Campbell, for his Consideration.— There was some conversation upon the Warrant for the delivery of the Passamaquoddy Islands; and question to whom it should be sent—which was not settled— The appointment of Mr Little as one of the new Appraizers of Merchandize at Boston was determined—that of the second postponed: At the President’s request we all went out with him and viewed the ground where they have begun digging for the foundation of one of the new Executive Offices. We all agreed that the place where they have begun is not well chosen and that another should be selected. But the opinions differed whether the new Scites should be parallel to the present buildings; or at right angles with them— It was three O’Clock when I returned to my Office. Received a numerous Mail of Letters— A Short Evening— When I rise so early, I find writing or reading after dinner quite impracticable. But for study; one morning hour is worth two in the Evening.

14. IV:30. Morning engaged with this Journal, and afterwards drafting a despatch to A. Gallatin. At Noon I attended at my Office where I had successively as visitors Ficklin, Consul at the Swedish Island of St. Bartholomew’s, who says he came home because he was not allowed to exercise the Consular functions there, and who strongly recommends the purchase of the Island itself by the United States— He is to call again to-morrow— Isaac Waters of Boston, who came to renew his solicitation for the new appointment of appraizer, and A. C. Mitchell, who brought a Letter from W. D. Robinson, still a prisoner at Campecha. Mr Bagot applied for an interview, for which I fixed to-morrow three O’Clock. The Northern Mail came in so late, that it was brought to me at my house, after I came home to dinner— I find myself much affected by the weather, which has been these two days at summer heat. It disables me altogether from writing, after dinner.

15. IV:30. Finished the draft of a despatch to A. Gallatin; but the remainder of the Morning till Noon was idled away. At the President’s I met Mr Crowninshield. The President spoke to me with some regret that he could not bestow one of the Appraizer’s Offices at Boston, upon William Foster junr. and directed me to write to him and offer him that of Consul at the Island of St. Thomas. When I came to the Office, I found Mr Bagot already there. He came to make the proposals, already broached by Lord Castlereagh to Mr Rush, stating that with regard to the Slaves carried from the United States by British Officers after the late Peace, the British Government accepted the proposal made by that of the United States, to refer the question of Construction of the Treaty which has arisen upon it, to the arbitration of a friendly Sovereign— But it was thought advisable to take as a previous measure the course of the Treaty in regard to other questions between the parties, and to refer the question to Commissioners mutually chosen. At the same time it was wished to take the opportunity for settling another and the only remaining question of
boundary between the two Countries; namely that of the line from the North-west corner of the lake of the Woods, westward— It had been left undetermined at the Treaty of Ghent; though it was known that the line of the Treaty of 1783 was a nullity, and the Treaty of 1794, by which some provision was made for the difficulty, no longer existed.— And as our Settlements westward were on both sides pushing on very rapidly, it was very desirable, that the present favorable moment should be taken for coming to an arrangement of the question; which it was proposed to do also by the means of Commissioners I observed to him that there was a third question which had also been suggested by Lord Castlereagh to Mr Rush; that relating to Columbia river. He said he considered it as involved in the other. And he further observed that his Government had been a little hurt at learning from him of the Ontario’s having been despatched to take possession of the Mouth of Columbia River, without giving notice to him of the measure. That his Government in the fullest and most explicit manner admitted the obligation of restoring any Post, which had existed there at the commencement of the late War under the authority of the United States. That on receiving information of the Ontario’s expedition immediate orders had been issued from the Lords of the Admiralty, to prevent any collision in the Execution of the Ontario’s orders— That no resistance would be made against them; but he was instructed to add that the British Government did not admit the validity of our title to that territory— I told him that although I was here when the Ontario sailed, the measure had been determined upon, before I came— That I should inform the President of the substance of his communication; but in the meantime I could assure him that the omission to give him notice of the object of that expedition, was not from any intentional concealment; but altogether in consequence of the answer given by Mr Baker, when in 1815. the restoration of that Post had been demanded by Mr Monroe— Which was that the American Post, at the mouth of Columbia river, taken by the British during the War, had not been occupied by them, but immediately abandoned— That concluding thence, that there was no British Post there, the Ontario had been sent there with instructions to persons on board merely to resume the possession of the United States; and as it was expected that no British Post would be found there, it had not occurred that there was any occasion to give notice of the expedition to him, or to his Government. He said he was entirely satisfied with this explanation which he was sure would be equally satisfactory to his Government. I said that no force was intended to be used in the execution of this Service— The Officers charged with it were instructed if they should find any settlement there, and any opposition made to their taking possession, not to commit any act of hostility or of force. He said no resistance would be made— I told him that we had no thoughts of making War, at present for the Empire of Astoria, but, with regard to the title we had not only that settlement actually established before the late War, but a purchase of a large tract of the Country made from the Indians in the year 1787. more than thirty years since— He said he had never heard of that before— I told him I was not aware of any material objection that there would be to referring these Subjects to Commissioners, unless it should be the dissatisfaction, which has been manifested in Congress at the slowness, and expensiveness of the Commissions now in operation. But there were other Subjects to be arranged between the two Countries— There were the fisheries— The renewal of commercial arrangements, to meet the expiration of the Convention of 3. July 1815— The additional Articles proposed by Lord Castlereagh, and, I hoped some further liberal provision with regard to the West-India trade. A hope that I the more freely indulged after seeing Lord Castlereagh’s Speech in February last, in answer to Mr Lyttleton’s questions on the Slave trade abolition Treaty, with Spain. He said those remarks of Lord Castlereagh had been generally, and much applauded every where in England— With regard to the Convention of 1815, the impression of many of the merchants among us here, was that its operation was disadvantageous to us, and to the advantage of Great-Britain. Yet I believed rather than incur the greater evil, of setting the whole business afloat again; of reviving the discriminating duties on both sides, and letting loose, all the petty fractious regulations, so troublesome to the merchants, we should be willing to agree at all Events that the duration of the Convention should be prolonged for some years: but if Great-Britain objects to that, and prefers that the Convention should be permitted to expire it will be necessary to give notice of it very soon; that the Merchants may be prepared accordingly. To all this Mr Bagot fully agreed.
As to the fisheries he said he regretted very much not having received from us the proposal that had been promised him; as now the Legislature of Nova-Scotia had taken up the subject— They were addressing the crown, and although their influence might be not very great, yet it must always be something— I said I hoped they would not listen to the Nova-Scotia Legislature, who suffered their temper to run away with their interest. They had found themselves compelled to repeal their Plaister Law, and now took up the fisheries by way of avenging themselves. If they were suffered to have their way they would make perpetual war between Great-Britain and the United States He said that was very true. But that we did not seem to think the complaints of the great inconveniences suffered by the British, in consequence of our fishermen frequenting their coast, were well founded. I said we knew very well there was the inconvenience of competition. Their fishermen would be better satisfied if they had the whole Coast to themselves— This was an old inconvenience which had always existed when the fishery was common to the French and English— The competition also sometimes gave rise to quarrels between the fishermen of the different Nations— That was an inconvenience, but it did not affect the question of right. He said he alluded to the opportunities afforded for smuggling. I said there might have been something in that, at one particular period of time before the late War; when large American ships went there and took Cargoes for Europe— A state of things which probably would never happen again— Our fishing vessels now and in all ordinary times were small; without Cargoes; frequenting chiefly a desert Coast, where there could be no smuggling. I thought there was very little cause for such complaint now— The case of one of our vessels seized last Summer at St. Andrew’s about which I had written to him, shewed there was much more suspicion than real smuggling on that Coast— As to the proposal, which was to have been made to the British Government, and which had hitherto been delayed, its postponement had been owing to difficulties which had been discovered since it was promised. It was founded on the principle of assuming a range of Coast within given Latitudes, for our fishermen to frequent, and abandoning the right to fish for the rest— But the fish themselves resorted at different times to different parts of the Coast, and a place which might be selected as very eligible now, might be in the course of four or five years entirely deserted. For my own part I had always been averse to any proposal of accommodation— I thought our whole right as stipulated by the Treaty of 1783 so clear, that I was for maintaining the whole, and if force should be applied to prevent our fishermen from frequenting the Coast, I would have protested against it, and reserved the right of recovering the whole by force, whenever we should be able. It had however been determined, otherwise here, and a proposal had been promised. Perhaps we should ultimately offer to give up the right of drying and curing on the shore, and reserve the whole right of fishing— He said that whatever was done, he hoped to hear from me again soon, upon this, and the other subjects of this interview— W. Lee called upon me to propose to me from Mr R. Parrott, the purchase of fifty acres of land upon Rock Creek, and adjoining the City. Parrott also proposed it to me by Letter. I agreed with Lee to go and view it with him to-morrow Evening, if fair weather— Received despatches from R. Rush, and Jonn: Russell; which I sent over to the President— The weather is again cool, and I was able to write, after dinner— Mrs Adams was unwell.

16. IV:30. May-Storm— Began soon after Sun rise this morning and continued without intermission through the day. I rode to the President’s and home from the Office. The journal of yesterday occupied the Morning; and the Newspapers the Evening, after dinner— I read over the despatches received from R. Rush, with a view to prepare answers to them— The President returned me the draft of the despatch to Mr Gallatin, with some alterations— He also directed me to see Mr G. Graham, and enquire if he would go to Galveston, and ascertain the object of the recent lodgment there, by the Frenchmen under L’Allemand, and to warn them that they are upon the territory of the United States— He proposes at the same time to send a secret Agent, to Pensacola to watch the movements there, particularly with regard to the illicit introduction of slaves
from thence into the United States— W. Lee called at the Office, and we postponed until Monday our walk to view Mr Parrott’s lands— R. Kemper came, and said he was now prepared with his lawyer Walter Jones, for his interview with the President and me, relative to the West-Florida Accounts. I advised him to go to the President’s and get a time fixed for this purpose. The President appointed twelve O’Clock next Monday of which Kemper came and gave me notice— I received a Letter from John Vaughan of Philadelphia, enclosing one from R. M. Patterson Secretary to the American Philosophical Society, informing me of my having been elected on the 17th: of April last, a member of that body, with the Certificate of election, and a pamphlet containing the Laws and Regulations of the Society— My time was much hurried at the Office, and not a little of the current business was left undone.

17. V:30. The Storm subsided, but the weather remained dull and unsettled. Mary-Hellen was taken with a violent fever, and confined to her chamber. Dr Hunt attends her. Morning visit from E. Vail. R. Kemper was here, and said the President had altered the arrangement which he had appointed yesterday, and would see me, before or after he, Kemper, and his lawyer, W. Jones, shall have been with him to-morrow— I met W. Lee walking, and went with him and viewed the Land offered for sale by Mr. Parrott on the borders of the City. It gave me a walk of near three hours— While at home I was engaged all the day and Evening; writing private Letters— Antoine was ill in bed, with a fever.

18. VI:Mr Greuhm, the Prussian Minister Resident and Consul General, came to take leave. He goes the day after to-morrow upon a tour of two Months to New-York and Boston— The weather continues bad— Rain almost the whole day. Mr. J. M. Baker a perpetual solicitor of Office came and occupied about an hour of my time— The Office of Consulor commercial agent at Porto-Rico, was his last request, and the President had consented to let him have it. He now came to say that he had been to Baltimore to look out for a passage and found there was no vessel going. That he had been to Mr Onis for Letters of Recommendation. Onis had promised him a Letter for the Intendant; but told him he would not be permitted to stay there— That he found there was very little commerce with Porto-Rico, and in short that he wanted another place. For instance, he would like to be Secretary of Legation to Russia—to go with Mr Campbell. I told him I believed that place was supplied; but promised to mention him again to the President for any vacancy that may occur. Mr Kemper came about his Florida claims with Mr W. Jones, his Counsel. After some discussion of their merits, he concluded to apply with them again to Mr Pleasonton the Auditor— There was in the year 1811 an insurrection in West-Florida, against the then existing Spanish Government there— It was managed entirely by Americans, of whom Kemper was one of the most active. They formed a Convention, and constituted a Republic, and made war upon Spain, until the Spanish Governor Folch applied to the Government of the U.S. to take possession of the Country, which they did, and have kept it ever since— The insurgent Convention men then applied to Congress for the payment of their expenses, and for compensation for this insurgency; and Congress in 1814. passed an act, authorising the Secretary of State to adjust and settle these claims. Mr Monroe appointed Kemper, Commissioner to go and collect the claims which he has done— It was understood when the Act of Congress passed, that their amount should not exceed 40,000 dollars. The auditor under Instructions from the acting Secretary of State, Mr Rush, has already admitted claims to the amount of more than 40,000 dollars, and there remain claims not admitted, of about 30000 dollars more; a large part of which are for Kemper himself. When I came home to dinner P. Ford the man who is begging for a place in some custom house followed me there, and kept me another long hour, dwelling upon the details of his distress, and the wants of his wretched family— Mary Hellen and Antoine are still confined with fevers— Evening idle.

19. IV:30.Mrs Adams quite unwell. Mary Hellen continues ill with her fever, but is better— Antoine was up, part of the day; but not fully recovered— Rain and Thunder, this Morning. Towards night the weather became fair. Finished a draft of a despatch to R. Rush, which I took to the President. He renewed the suggestion, which he had made once or twice before of a wish to propose to Great-Britain a general negotiation of a commercial Treaty to include the continuation of the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. and to embrace the other objects
in discussion between the two Governments— Such as the Affair of the Slaves—the Fisheries—the Boundary from the Lake of the Woods—and Columbia river. He thought it would be necessary to give Mr . . ., a Colleague for this Negotiation, and asked my opinion concerning it. I said I believed the best thing that could be done would be to join Mr Gallatin with him for this Negotiation— He said there was only one objection that occurred to him; which was that they were both from the same State— I thought that of no consequence in this case. Mr Gallatin not being a native of Pennsylvania, and not having resided there nearly for the last twenty years. The President assented, and directed me to draw further Instructions for Gallatin and Rush, accordingly. At the Office, I sent for Mr G. Graham, and proposed to him to go, upon the confidential mission to Galveston, to ascertain what L’allemand, and his party are doing there—under what authority they made the lodgment, and what are their intentions— At the same time to give them warning that they are upon the Territory of the United States. Graham said he had projected visiting the Alabama Territory this Summer and might perhaps ultimately settle there— He said he would give me an answer to the proposal in two or three days— Major Miller came to recommend his brother, for a consulate on the Oronoke river; and Coll. Lane came to ask my opinion with regard to the erection of the new Public Buildings— They are to contain each forty-rooms, and some question has arisen, whether they should nevertheless be of the same dimensions with the two existing buildings which contain only 26 Rooms each—I told Coll. Lane, I thought that was an absurdity. Dr. Bartlett of Charlestown left a Letter at the Office, from Dr Welsh, and as I was coming home, I met him walking in the avenue. He is making a tour for his health, and has been to Mount Vernon. He leaves the City to-morrow, on his return home. Mrs Adams was very unwell the whole day— Mary Hellen is yet confined with her fever; and Antoine though up, a part of the day, is not recovered. Received two boxes of Garden Seeds from Baltimore and London— A box containing Cloathing for me, from New-York and London; and two Barrels and a firkin, from Boston, sent by Mr Cruft.

20. V: Drafted a second despatch to R. Rush. The Correspondence of the Department is in great confusion for want of a proper system of order in conducting it— I found none established, and when I entered the Office no minute was kept even of the Letters received from day to day— I began soon after by having such an entry made in a Book, every day, and find it a very useful record, but it is not sufficient. I am constantly receiving notes from the Foreign Ministers residing here, and despatches from the Ministers of the United States abroad, on an immense variety of Subjects many of which require measures to be adopted before answers can be given and various delays— Whenever a subject is postponed, the multiplicity of affairs occurring from day to day, expels it from the memory; and without some thread by which to return to it, no recollection of it is retained. I have thus now eleven despatches from Rush, to answer at once—and a number nearly equal from J. Russell at Stockholm; from A. Gallatin at Paris, and from G.W. Erving at Madrid—besides Sumter, W. Pinkney and W. Eustis— I began by reading over all Rush’s despatches, and made a short minute of their contents— It has suggested to me the idea, of keeping an index of diplomatic Correspondence, in which each despatch from every Minister abroad shall be entered as it is received; and a minute of its contents and enclosures added, preparatory to its being answered. Also a similar Register for the Consular Correspondence, and for that with the foreign Ministers here. At the President’s this morning, I met Mr Ficklin, the Consul at St. Bartholomew’s. The President proposed to call a Cabinet meeting for twelve O’Clock to-morrow, to consider the expediency of offering a new commercial Negotiation with Great-Britain, and of joining Mr. Gallatin for it with Rush. But he postponed this call, Mr Calhoun being confined to his house, unwell— Mr Ten Cate came to my Office, at three O’Clock, wishing that the Instructions might immediately given from the Treasury Department for the return of extra Tonnage duties levied upon vessels of the Netherlands, the last year— He told me that he expected to be very shortly recalled; the king having destined him to another appointment. He had also
some questions whether a foreign consular agent here, could act in that capacity without having received an exequatur— I took a short walk with Mrs Adams after dinner— Mary Hellen is recovering; but Antoine is yet very ill.

21. IV:45. Prepared a despatch for Jonathan Russell, Minister at Stockholm— For which purpose I found it necessary to read over eleven despatches received from him since his return there— All received since the adjournment of Congress. Several of these referred to his prior correspondence which it became necessary to have looked up at the Office— As however the despatch must be forwarded as soon as possible, I made the draft; leaving the subjects upon which my information is incomplete to be taken up hereafter in another Letter— On reading my draft to the President, he wished it to be made more explicit, in letting Mr. Russell know that his mission must terminate in the course of the present year; and that he must not expect at present any further employment by the Executive in Europe. And in doing this, he wished me to express to him, the satisfaction of the President, with his conduct while he has been in the Public Service in Europe— I suggested to the President that Mr Russell was a man, who would consider that such a conclusion should not flow from such premises. That he had a high opinion of his own merits and services, and was by no means disposed to quit his hold upon Diplomatic employment— That in short he would not easily get rid of him. He said in a quick and sharp tone that he could assure me he should get very easily rid of him— I observed that Mr Russell had very explicitly told me that he considered himself entitled to a better mission than that of Sweden— Entitled, said the President!— no man in this Country is entitled to any appointment from the Executive— I said that was my own opinion; but it was not Mr Russell’s, and assuredly in whatever way he should discover that the President did not intend to employ him any further it would give him great offence, which he would take care should not remain unknown— The President said I might then leave my despatch to him as I had written the draft. As Mr Calhoun continues indisposed, the President directed me to send the second despatch to Mr Rush, round to the other heads of Departments and if they agreed to the measure of proposing the new commercial Negotiation to the British Government it might be determined upon, without calling a Cabinet Meeting. At the Office I found a Mail containing two despatches with a multitude of papers, and books from R. Rush— Two despatches from G. W. Erving. Two from W. Pinkney, and one from Jonn: Russell, with a Letter from the King of Sweden to the President and Senate of the United States: and many other Letters— Mr Bagot called upon me to enquire about indemnity to the owners of a British vessel captured in the East India Seas, by Captain Warrington, after the period fixed for the cessation of hostilities. He asked if it would be necessary to have a decision of a Court of Admiralty as a foundation for this claim, as Warrington himself would not deny the facts— I told him as the provision for the payment must be made by Congress, I could not say what Evidence they would require; and it would be best that he should write me a Note about it— I was detained at the Office till half past five, by a threatening thunder Storm— I walked home however while it was coming on. I had not been five minutes in my house, when it came on in its utmost fury, with a shower of hailstones which broke us about fifty Squares of window glass, at the North-side of the house; and my thermometer fixed outside of one of the windows. The Hail lasted about half an hour; but the thunder gusts were repeated, and returned with great violence, for the space of four or five hours, with incessant thunder and lightening. The window glass was shattered all over the house— Evening of course idle.

22. V: Weather fair, but sultry all the morning, but towards evening turned cool. No Fires in our sitting rooms. I read over the Correspondence of Jonathan Russell, while negotiating the Treaty of Commerce with Sweden. but several of his Letters are missing and not to be found on the files of the Department— Among them are his most important Letter on the subject of claims on the Swedish Government, and even the English translation of his Treaty is no where to be found— So it is with almost every Correspondence in the Department— All in disorder and confusion— Mr Brent came this morning and brought a pamphlet, borrowed, at the Office of the Clerk of the Senate— It was printed for the use of the Senators while they had the Treaty under Consideration and contains two of the papers missing in manuscript—namely Russells Letter sent with the Treaty; and the English translation of the Treaty, the original of which is in French— I gave Mr Brent directions for having the Copy of the Treaty with the ratification of it made out, to be signed— But the morning was absorbed in reading the papers and in discovering that those the most essential for preparing instructions to Russell concerning the claims, are not to be found— When I called at the President’s he was gone out riding—he afterwards sent me word that he was at home, but when I went to his house he was at dinner, and
I postponed seeing him till to-morrow. At the Office, Mr M. H. Aguirre came to inform me that he was about to return to his own Country, having concluded the object of his Mission. I had some conversation with him and found his information even concerning the affairs of his own country very imperfect. His visit; and the Mail of the day absorbed my time, so that I had none left for commencing my plan of Indexes to the Diplomatic and Consular Correspondences— After returning home I drafted an answer to the despatch from Mr Russell enclosing the Letter from the king of Sweden— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen were out fishing— After dinner we took a ride of an hour in the Carriage.

23. V: Prepared a Letter to R. Rush, in answer to those last received from him. It related to his account, and objected to some of his charges for contingencies. On reading it to the President he recommended that it should be sent as a private Letter, and it was copied accordingly. A Mr Gill came to the Office with a Letter requesting a document to shew that the little St. Mary’s river is within the Territory of East-Florida. This evidence is wanted for the case of a vessel called the Sabine, pending in England. Mr Calhoun brought me several Letters from a College in South Carolina, addressed to me as President of the Phi Beta Kappa Society, requesting that a Branch of the Society may be established there. The Letters are from Robert Elfe, Josiah J. Kilpatrick, Thomas H. Taylor, Francis H. Wardlaw, and Joseph N. Whitner, a Committee of the Students requesting the establishment of a Branch—from Jonathan Maxcy, the President of the College, and from Abraham Nott one of the Trustees, recommending, the object of the Petition— There were also, a printed Catalogue, of the Trustees, Faculty and Students of the College, a copy of the Laws, and a Catalogue of their Library— Mr Calhoun who was a member of the Society when an undergraduate at Yale College, recommended the writers of these Letters, as persons of the most respectable character; and at my desire promised to write me a Letter to that effect— I called at his office to make an arrangement for sending the Warrant to the Lieutenant Governor of Nova-Scotia, for the delivery of Moose, Frederick and Dudley Islands— The President had thought of sending General Miller from Boston. Mr Calhoun thought Miller should be ordered to send some Officer under his command— I concluded to take further directions concerning it from the President. R. Kemper came, and occupied me an hour or more, with his accounts and his complaints against Pleasonton, and his Clerk Ross. And thus as usual the Office hours wasted away; and with the reading and entering of the Letters of the daily mail, and signing a number of Blank Patents, brought me to half past five O’Clock, when I had barely commenced the perusal of Mr Gallatin’s despatches during his Mission to France, with a view to making the Index to Diplomatic Correspondence.— After dinner I took an hour’s walk with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen.

24. V:Mrs. Caldwell, sister of G. Boyd, died at five this morning— I have a number of private Letters to write, and hoped to have had time to write several of them this day— But it wasted itself, and left them almost all yet to be written— Mr D. Brent was here with Letters to the Collectors of Baltimore, Philadelphia, and New York, enquiring if there is at either of those Ports any vessel, bound immediately to Gothenburg, or up the Baltic; by which we can send the ratified Treaty, and my despatches to Jonn. Russell— Cardelli was here also, and gave us some account of the Works at the Capitol, where 45 Stone cutters have abandoned their work, because they demand two dollars and a half wages, by the day, while Coll. Lane, the Commissioner allows only two and a quarter. They have been idle near a whole month, and have lost more than the difference between their demand, and what the Commissioner offers would amount to in the whole Season— I walked beyond the Tiber, and round by the Point— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen passed the Evening at Boyd’s.

25. V:Mr Onis the Spanish Minister paid a visit, to take leave—going with his family to pass the Summer Months at Bristol, Pennsylvania. He said something about the Note he sent me last week against the late Settlement of Frenchmen under Lallemand at Galveston. I told him he knew more about it than we did— That we
might perhaps send troops to break up the establishment, and take possession of the place as being within our Territory, but he had objected to such a measure heretofore— He said he had thought such violent measures unnecessary, and they certainly would be so now, as the Viceroy of Mexico, wrote him that he had eighty thousand men under his command; upon which I laughed heartily— You laugh said Onis, at my saying the Vice Roy has 80000 men— No said I; but I was thinking how easily the Viceroy with that army will dispose of 150 Frenchmen under Lallemand— But said Onis, there are two thousand of them— My word for it said I, not two hundred— Well, said he, as for the viceroy’s 80,000 men, I do not vouch for them, but so I assure you he writes to me— He said he was very confident of the success of Spain at Buenos-Ayres but he was afraid of the War of Carraccas— That Bolívar had been totally defeated by Morillo, so that the War would have been at an end; but Bolivar had received after the Battle a reinforcement of four whole English regiments of men which had enabled him to resume the offensive; and now he was afraid even for Carthagena and Porto Bello— He spoke with much exasperation against the English, and said he had always advised his Government against referring the contest with the colonies to the mediation of the allies— I told him there was a young man named Serra, (he said it must be Cerna) coming out to him; at which he appeared to be somewhat surprized— Mr G. Graham also called this morning, and told me he should be ready to go, the beginning of next week— I was but a couple of hours at the Office; and at four O’Clock went & attended the funeral of Mrs Caldwell, from her husband’s house. Mr Frye, W. S. Smith and Bulfinch went with me in the procession— There was a prayer at the house, and an exhortation at the grave by Mr Breckenridge, and a short prayer, also at the grave by Mr Lowrier. It was near seven O’Clock when I got home.

26. IV:30. I received this morning a note from the President appointing a Cabinet Meeting at 12 O’Clock. Mr G. Hay called and paid me a visit. I made a draft of a despatch to Mr Gallatin, preparatory to the proposal for a negotiation of a new Commercial Treaty with England— At noon I attended the Meeting at the President’s. All the members of the Administration were there. The President proposed the consideration of the questions whether the new Negotiation should be proposed to the British Government, and whether in the event of their accepting the proposal, Mr Gallatin should be joined with Mr Rush, for the management of it, on our part— The opinion in favour of both measures was unanimous. There was much Conversation upon the various subjects which would be included in the Negotiation; but no apparent difference of opinion upon any of them. The president directed me to prepare the instructions and documents to be forwarded for this joint mission. I left with him the draft of the despatch to Mr Gallatin, for his revisal— It was past three when I went to my office— On my return home to dinner, I found a Letter from Mr W. Pinkney our late Minister to Russia, at Annapolis, dated the 23d. he had just arrived there from Bremen— I spent the Evening with Mrs Adams at Commodore Decatur’s— The party small— The foreign Ministers were there. Mr Bagot told me he should send a Messenger, next Monday; and asked an interview with me in the interval, to which I agreed. Mr Hyde de Neuville spoke to me of certain claims which he has made in favour of French vessels for admission to the Ports of Louisiana upon more favourable terms than those of other Nations. I told him there was not a shadow of reason for the claim; upon which he said he would write me a note; and told me that the opinion of a person very high in this Government, and for whom I had the highest respect, was different from mine— There was music by Mr Ten Cate, Madame de Heredia, Miss Bridon, and the Misses Middleton— This was the first, and a very warm Summer’s day— Winter Cloathing discarded.

27. VI. Morning wasted in reading Newspapers. At the President’s and took his directions upon various subjects. He goes to-morrow Morning to Annapolis, upon his tour down Chesapeake-Bay; to be gone about three weeks— I attended the Meeting of the four heads of Departments at the War-Office. Some regulations were agreed to, among which was one prohibiting the Clerks in the public Offices from acting as Agents for the claims of individuals. A Superintendent of the Building in which the Offices of the State, War and Navy Departments are kept was appointed jointly by Mr Calhoun, Mr Crowninshield and me. There were several applications among which three or four of Clerks in the various departments. We fixed upon a man named Dogherty who was one of Mr Jefferson’s Servants while he was President— I sent over to the President despatches received from Mr Sumter at Rio Janeiro, and he returned to me the draft of despatch to Mr Gallatin— He sent me in the Evening directions to arrange with the Secretary of War, the manner of taking possession of Moose-Island— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen rode out in the Carriage after dinner— Weather oppressively hot all day. Thermometer at 82. Evening thunder shower.

28. V:30. The President left the City early this morning for Annapolis; going from thence down Chesapeake Bay by water to Norfolk, and to be absent about three weeks— The Secretaries of War and of the Navy are going with him; and from Norfolk Mr Calhoun goes for two Months to South-Carolina, and Mr Crowninshield for four or five to Massachusetts— I drafted a Letter to the Secretary of War, requesting him to issue instructions to detach an Officer, to go and take possession of Moose-Island, jointly with the Sheriff of the County of Washington in the State of Massachusetts—and also a form of a Warrant to them jointly to receive possession, to be signed by the President. I was taking these papers to Mr Calhoun’s house to consult with him upon them, when I met him and Crowninshield in a Carriage, going to Annapolis— Mr Calhoun took my drafts with him to the President for his final determination upon them— At the Office I had as visitors, Mr G. Gill, who applied for an official Certificate that the Little Saint Mary’s river is in East-Florida, and within the Spanish Territory. He brought a printed copy of Ellicott’s journal as evidence of the fact, but I declined giving the certificate as unusual. Mr M. M. Russell came to announce that having been to Liverpool on his way to Riga, where he was appointed Consul; he had been obliged by the ill health of his wife to return immediately to this Country; and now would be glad to have the Consulate of Tunis, or any other, that should be profitable— Then Mr G. S. Johonnot, who brought me strong Letters of recommendation from Judge Story and Mr Silsbee. He had been sometime bondsman for his brother as Navy agent at Boston, and he proving a delinquent, and since dead, this person has been sued upon his bond. He brought me the papers of the case from the navy department, and requested me to see the Comptroller judge Anderson, who had told him he must consult me before he could make up his decision, upon the extent of his responsibility, and he wanted to leave the City to-morrow Morning— I went over to Anderson’s office, and after a perusal of the papers and a discussion upon them with Anderson, he told me, it was not me, but the Secretary of the Treasury whom he had told Johonnot that he must consult with before deciding on his Account— Thus my Office hours were absorbed, and nothing done— In the Evening Mrs Adams went to her sister Boyd’s, and I took a solitary walk round the Capitol Hill.

29. IV:30. Wrote a private Letter to R. Rush. Mr Edward Cruft of Boston called early this morning. He arrived in the City last Evening with Mrs Cruft, being upon a Southern tour, for the benefit of her health. She suffers with a pulmonary complaint, and had been confined to her chamber for three Months before they left Boston— He had several of the old Loan Office Certificates issued in 1777. and 1778. with an Indent of Interest of 1781. which had never been funded, and which he had found among the papers of the late Mr William Smith, Mrs Cruft’s father, and which appeared to have been the property of Mrs Smith’sfather, N. Carter of Newbury-Port— The production of these papers as claims against U.S. has been barred for many years, till the limitations were suspended for two years by an Act of Congress at their last Session— I went with him to the Office of the Register of the Treasury Mr Nourse, where the papers were found to be all good, and he was promised warrants for the Money, to be ready for him To-morrow Morning. They amounted to near 3000 dollars— He had also an order upon the Navy Department, for which I went with him to the Office of Mr Homans the Chief Clerk— He afterwards called and passed an hour with me at my Office— W. S. Smith came with a Letter to me to ask me to assist in relieving him from his difficulties. He has now two Writs served upon him for debts due by him at New-York; but stated that 1500 dollars would set him at ease from his immediate embarrassments: he came to my house again this Evening, and confirmed what I had already reason to believe, that he had imprudently made himself responsible for all his fathers debts. I told him therefore that I would give him all the aid in my power; but it could not be by paying his debts— I advised him of the course which I thought he ought to pursue. He will converse to-morrow Morning with Mr Law, the Attorney who issued the writs against him, and call here again. Mr Bagot came by appointment to the Office at two O’Clock, and I had an hour’s Conversation with him— I told him of the offer which the President had
determined to make, to negotiate a general Treaty of Commerce, embracing the continuance of the commercial Convention of 3. July 1815. and mentioned the other objects which it was proposed to include in the Treaty— He said he did not know that there would be any objection to it on the part of his Government— Mrs. Adams was this Evening at her sister Frye’s— Thomas Hellen was nearly drowned this day in the river. Taken apparently dead out of the water; and with difficulty recovered to life.

30. V:Mrs Adams went early this morning to Mrs Frye’s to see Thomas Hellen, who was so far recovered as to be taken home from the house to which he had been carried when taken out of the water, and from whence he could not be last Evening removed— I called upon Mr and Mrs. Cruft, at Mrs Mather’s on the Capitol Hill— At the Office Mr Ten Cate, the Chargé d’Affaires from the Netherlands came to mention that he had received his Letter of Recall; but as he should not for a week or ten days be ready to go, he would if I pleased until then postpone delivering it to me; and in the meantime would send me a copy of it; to which I agreed, and which he did. He asked for a time to call upon me and present Mr. Lechleitner who is to be an intermediate Chargé d’Affaires here, until the arrival of Ten Cate’s successor— I fixed next Monday at two O’Clock, for that purpose. Mr R. Kemper came also to the Office, upon his West-Florida claim Accounts and now brought with him, Mr Hugh Nelson a member of the House of Representatives from Virginia, and a particular friend of the Presidents, who urged his claim and argued his cause with great earnestness— This is a case of a discretionary power given by a special Act of Congress to the Secretary of State; which had been carried into effect almost completely by Mr Rush, who in admitting about half the claims, had rejected the rest. Kemper applies to me, to admit the claims rejected by Rush, for which I see no sufficient cause. I told them I should report the new suggestions of Judge Nelson to the President and act conformably to his instructions— This Evening there came an Express from the President at Annapolis, with a Letter from him, directing me how to proceed, for taking possession of the Islands in Passamaquoddy Bay. He concludes to send General Miller, as sole Commissioner; and to give notice to the Governor of Massachusetts, and invite him to appoint some Officer of the State to be present at the surrender.

31. VI: The Express from Annapolis came this Morning for the settlement of his Account, but having no order from the Post-master at Annapolis who sent him, I gave him a receipt for the packet and referred him back for the order— I drafted the Instructions to General Miller, and a Letter to the Governor of Massachusetts according to the President’s directions. Mr Baker, the British Consul came and told me he had received a leave of absence for eight Months, and proposed to leave the City the day after to-morrow, offering to take any orders for England. He said Mr Bagot had told him of the intended offer to negotiate a new Commercial Treaty— I walked before dinner, over the Tiber, and to the Banks of the Potowmack near the Bridge, where I took a river Bath— Mr and Mrs Cruft dined with us, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here. Received a card of invitation to attend the funeral of Mrs Barlow to-morrow Morning at ten O’Clock— She died after a lingering illness this morning.

Day. The adjournment of Congress has not yet procured me any leisure. Business has been and continues to be crowded upon me without intermission; and if there comes a single day, when the pressure is such as admits of postponement, I waste it in idleness. I rise between five and six; Read and asort Newspapers, and write journal or Letters till twelve; with the interval, between nine and eleven—of an hour at breakfast, and often of another hour or more, by visitors— Sollicitors for Office or applicants—generally troublesome and importunate. About noon I go to the President’s, and am with him from one to two hours—reading papers to him; consulting concerning them and taking his directions. Between one and two I reach my Office, about the time when the Northern Mail comes in— Visitors at the Office, and reading and entering the Letters employ me till five or half an hour later. I get home to dinner at six; and from seven till ten, am reading the Newspapers of which from twenty to thirty come every day— I retire to bed usually about ten—
